title: 108_hr239
content: The Act is titled the "Brownfields Redevelopment Enhancement Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purposes. The Congress finds that returning brownfield sites to productive use could create jobs and generate new tax revenues, while also protecting natural resources and open spaces. Lack of funding for redevelopment is a major obstacle, and the Department of Housing and Urban Development plays a key role in supporting community development and land use in urban areas through grants under the Brownfields Economic Development Initiative. The Department of Housing and Urban Development's initiative provides funding for brownfields redevelopment, including land acquisition and economic development activities. To be eligible for grant funds, communities must pledge community development block grant funds as collateral for a loan guarantee. Delinking grants from loan guarantees removes a barrier for many local communities. The Act aims to provide cities and towns with more flexibility and accessibility for brownfields development by offering incentives and separating grants for brownfields from community development block grant funds. SEC. 123 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 introduces the Brownfields Development Initiative to promote the redevelopment of contaminated sites. The Secretary may award grants to eligible public entities and Indian tribes for environmental cleanup and development of brownfield sites, including mine-scarred lands. Grant amounts must be used for specified activities and comply with certain requirements. The Secretary may award grants for environmental cleanup and brownfield site development to eligible public entities and Indian tribes. Grant recipients are not required to use the funds in connection with projects assisted by a guaranteed loan. Applications for assistance must follow procedures established by the Secretary. Selection criteria for grants may include leveraging of other funds for the projects. The grant amounts will fund projects and activities. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2004-2008. SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF BROWNFIELDS REDEVELOPMENT AS ELIGIBLE CDBG ACTIVITY. The penultimate proviso of the first undesignated paragraph in the Community Development Block Grants Fund section of the 1997 Appropriations Act is amended to align with the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. Additionally, amendments are made to the Act regarding Brownfields Redevelopment Activities. The 1997 Appropriations Act is amended to align with the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. Amendments are made to the Act regarding Brownfields Redevelopment Activities, including environmental cleanup and economic development related to brownfield projects. The 1997 Appropriations Act is amended to align with the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, including amendments related to Brownfields Redevelopment Activities. SEC. 5 introduces a Pilot Program for National Redevelopment of Brownfields. Section 108(q) of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 is amended to establish a pilot program for national redevelopment of brownfields. Grants will be used to create a common loan pool for brownfield redevelopment projects. The pilot program for national brownfield redevelopment includes a common loans loss reserve account for participants. The Secretary can select entities to manage the program, and eligible public entities must adhere to specified terms and conditions for participation. Appropriations are authorized for grants under this subsection. The grants under this subsection are to be used only in conjunction with the pilot program, ensuring its effective and efficient implementation. SEC. 6. Technical amendment allows CDBG funds for renewal communities. Section 105(a)(13) of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 is amended to include renewal communities. SEC. 7. The amendments apply to funds from fiscal year 2004 onwards for use under the amended law.
